newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Offshore scramble for future of Taiwan futures.
newsitem.headline: Offshore scramble for future of Taiwan futures.

text.p: A race for Taiwan's potentially significant futures market begins this week with a number of American exchanges vying for investors.

An aggressive, Asia-focused Chicago Mercantile Exchange had hoped to be first out of the gate Thursday with electronic trading of new futures and futures options contracts linked to Taiwan's stock market performance.

However, the CME is now expected to be overtaken by the Singapore International Monetary Exchange, or SIMEX, which will launch open-outcry trading of similar Taiwan index contracts just minutes earlier.
San Francisco's venerable Pacific Stock Exchange, bolstering its claim as a U.S. gateway to Asia's financial markets, will begin trading Taiwan stock-index options a day later.

All are defying Taiwan regulators' appeals to go slow in a race to meet what they call intense demand overseas -- and in Taiwan -- for derivatives linked to Taipei's effervescent stock market, one of the world's top 15 in capitalisation and turnover.
Taiwan has no local futures exchange, something long scorned as a gamblers' plaything with little legitimate value. Its stock exchange is unlikely to offer index options before mid-1997.

Playing for time to build a futures infrastructure, Taiwan has stopped short of deeming the rivals hostile but has withheld technical cooperation and threatened to cut off access to stock price data crucial to their indexes.
The fate of Taiwan's own planned futures exchange remains a hostage of parliament, still bickering over at least three rival drafts of an enabling Futures Trading Law.
At the same time, Taiwan's watchdog Securities and Exchange Commission has refused to let foreign financial institutions use the local exchange's proprietary TAIEX index.
Nor has it legalised trading of offshore Taiwan index futures by Taiwan brokerages or investors, who are expected to skirt the ban by opening "underground" accounts offshore.

Analysts say local investors, who can legally trade overseas commodities futures, have legitimate need of a stock market hedge. Experts estimate Taiwan stock-index futures could fuel T$50 billion (US$1.8 billion) a month in turnover the first year.
